p: These results largely agree with the notion of an environmental Kuznets curve 14, as shown in Fig. 4. Relatively low levels of pollution occur in both poor and rich nations due to, respectively, absence and control of pollution sources. Relatively high levels of pollution are found in rapidly developing nations characterized by urbanizing populations and expanding economies that have not yet implemented comprehensive control and treatment of pollution sources 15 16. There is however also large heterogeneity within countries. For example, China is one of the fastest growing economies in the world but its urban population and economic development are concentrated in the eastern part of the country. Likewise, organic river pollution is also concentrated in the east ( Fig. 2a), despite a higher rate of 55% wastewater treatment in eastern China compared to 20% in western China 17. While urban areas possess financial and technical resources for pollution control, control measures typically lag behind population increase.
